title: Vision Statement Specificity
content: A strong project vision should answer three key questions: What will change? For whom? By when? Avoid abstract statements like 'improve efficiency' without quantifiable targets. Include specific metrics (e.g., 'reduce processing time by 30%') or clear outcomes (e.g., 'enable same-day customer onboarding').

title: Clear Scope Boundaries
content: Define scope using the MECE principle: Mutually Exclusive, Collectively Exhaustive. Each in-scope item should be distinct (no overlap), and together they should cover everything the project will deliver. Out-of-scope items should explicitly list common assumptions that stakeholders might expect but won't be delivered.

title: Risk Category Coverage
content: A comprehensive risk assessment should cover at least five categories: (1) Technical risks - technology, integration, complexity; (2) Resource risks - staffing, skills, availability; (3) Schedule risks - dependencies, timeline compression; (4) Scope risks - requirements changes, scope creep; (5) External risks - vendors, regulations, market changes. Each risk should describe the potential impact, not just the risk event.

title: SMART Success Metrics
content: Success metrics should follow the SMART framework: Specific (clear what's being measured), Measurable (quantifiable), Achievable (realistic given constraints), Relevant (aligned with project goals), Time-bound (has a measurement period). Each metric needs a baseline, target, and measurement system. Avoid subjective metrics like 'improved satisfaction' without defining how satisfaction is measured.

title: Project Phase Coverage
content: Milestones should cover all standard project phases: Initiation (project kickoff, charter approval), Planning (requirements complete, design approved), Execution (development milestones, testing phases), and Closure (go-live, lessons learned). Each milestone should have a clear deliverable and target date. Avoid clustering all milestones at the end of the project.

title: Team Role Clarity
content: Core team definitions should follow RACI principles: each team member should have clear Responsibilities (what they do) and Accountabilities (what they own). Avoid generic role descriptions like 'helps with project'. Include key stakeholders who have decision-making authority, not just executors. For larger projects, distinguish between core team (daily involvement) and extended team (periodic involvement).

title: Problem Statement with Business Impact
content: A compelling problem statement should describe: (1) The current state (what's happening now), (2) The pain points (what problems this causes), (3) The business impact (quantified if possible - cost, time, risk). Avoid problem statements that only describe symptoms without root causes, or that assume a solution ('we need a new system').

title: Assumptions as Potential Risks
content: Every assumption is a potential risk if it proves false. Document assumptions explicitly and consider adding corresponding risks for critical assumptions. Common assumptions to document: resource availability, technology stability, stakeholder availability, budget approval, third-party dependencies. Each assumption should be validated early in the project.
